Award.AwardTitle: Points on Curves Over Finite Fields and Motivic Stabilization
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is to study the distribution of points on curves over a fixed finite field and stabilization of sequences of moduli spaces, especially of curves, in the Grothendieck ring of varieties. The question of distribution of points on curves in a family over a fixed finite field is quite mysterious, even on the heuristic level, but many recent developments allow interesting access to special cases. These cases can provide the groundwork for development of the general theory. Related questions of counting points on varieties over finite fields have recently been determined to reflect a deeper structure in the Grothendieck ring of varieties, which will be studied and further developed in this project.

A basic question about an equation is: how many solutions does it have? Many equations naturally fall into families of similar equations, for example, quadratic equations are ones in which all terms have degree at most two. This project studies how answers to the question of "how many solutions?" vary within a family and what consistent patterns develop as the family gets more complicated. The project also involves mentoring undergraduates, supporting infrastructure for networking and mentoring of women in mathematics, dissemination of mathematical ideas to middle school students, high school students, college non-math majors, and the general public, and mentoring and training graduate students

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed new understanding of foundational objects of mathematics: numbers, how they factor, and solutions to polynomial equations.  New insights on number theory, including prime numbers, were gained through forging deep connections between probability, topology, geometry, and number theory. 

One example of a result under this project is as follows. A fundamental principle of data analysis is that when you average many noisy observations, you can be confident they will settle down to a normal distribution, even if the noise in the data is too complicated to understand. This is a classical example of universality, a property of some random systems in which input parameters (here, the type of noise) can be changed and yet certain measured outputs are unchanged. One important activity of this project is that I have developed an analogous principle that can be applied to undetermined algebraic structures (like obstructions to unique factorization) instead of to noisy observations. I have proven that microstructure that we can not understand still aggregates into completely regular and predictable global behavior. A simple example is to pick a large random matrix of integers. What is the probability that the determinant is divisible by 10? Your first guess might be 10%, but in fact not only is it more, my work proves that the probability converges to a universal value, 17.04541688...%. This happens whenever the entries of a random matrix are independent and non­trivial, even (most importantly) if they are the result of an undetermined, complicated random process. Universality means that the output of a random system is the same for any input. So we can compute the output on simple inputs, and be certain that complicated or unknown inputs would give that same output. I used this idea to apply my universality results for random integral matrices to determine the distribution of sandpile groups, which have many interpretations including as algebraic structures which control the dynamics of sandpiles and avalanches and also control factorization in geometric number systems.

Undergraduates, graduate students, and postdocs were mentored in mathematical research, writing, and communication.
